chapter.title: Data Handling
chapter.para: This section covers how data is handled in Haiku Depot Server (HDS) in terms of its use and persistence from a user perspective.

section.title: Browser
section.para: A Browser is a piece of software that can be run on a computing device in order to view web sites and web applications. HDS is such a web application. Browsers such as Firefox and Google Chrome can be used to access HDS and as it does so, there is the possibility that some data may be stored in the Browser.

section.title: Tracking
section.para: HDS does not use a form of tracking technology with third-parties.

section.title: Cookies
section.para: HDS does not use Cookie technology.

section.title: Local Storage
section.para: Local Storage is a mechanism that is available in some Browsers for maintaining data in the Browser. HDS can optionally use local storage for conveniently storing some data for the user. Using the Browser's Local Storage is optional and the user is given the choice to allow or disallow HDS to use Local Storage. The HDS system is entirely functional without using Local Storage, but some aspects may not be as convenient. The data stored by HDS using Local Storage includes the following at the time of writing;

itemizedlist.listitem: The user of the Browser's preferred natural language such as English or Russian.

If applicable, the user's current authentication. This is convenient because the authentication is then able, for a short time, survive a Browser restart and is also able to be shared between tabs of the same Browser.

Some user selections related to search. For example, the user's selection of repositories. This is more convenient because the user does not need to re-select their repositories each time they open a new HDS Browser window.
